author: Matthew Dallas
title: International status well out of reach for Palmerston North Airport
text:
International status well out of reach for Palmerston North Airport MATTHEW DALLAS Last updated 05:00, September 4 2015 OPINION: 
As appealing and convenient as it would be to have trans-Tasman flights returned to Manawatu, it's about as plausible as attracting cruise ships to the region. 
Palmerston North Airport chief executive David Lanham has stamped out any suggestion the arrival of a Jetstar route between Manawatu and Auckland is the first step on the stairway back to international status. 
Regional centres are not viable options for international flights, the airlines aren't interested and it's not part of anyone's strategy - except perhaps Palmerston North mayor Grant Smith. 
He argues that Palmerston North still has an appetite for international services, and there is enough bright things on the city's horizon to make it profitable. 
There's nothing wrong with an optimistic city leader, but it's difficult to see Smith's stance as anything more than "never say never" perseverance, perhaps with a touch of denial. 
From the Manawatu perspective, flights to Sydney sound great, putting our region on a direct course to tourist destinations and friends and family across the Tasman. 
But the Sydney perspective is not so enthusiastic, particularly when one considers the main centres Australian visitors can fly to, cities and regions that have established tourism profiles. 
I'm not saying Manawatu doesn't have potential on this front, but we haven't yet cracked the code on how to sell our region to New Zealand let alone Australia. 
That airports in Hamilton, Hawke's Bay and Rotorua - that city which craves tourists more than Gollum does the one ring - have lost their international status, shows how hard it is to make these flights work outside of metropolitan areas. 
Smith says it has been sustainable before; Freedom Air from 1996 to 2008. But a lot has changed in the industry since then, with far more attractive areas of growth for airlines to pursue, and nothing to suggest lack of demand, which saw the no-frills airline axed seven years ago, has changed. Ad Feedback 
As Lanham suggest, Palmerston North Airport has more to gain from building on its domestic connections, rather than getting hung up on what we used to have but don't have now. 
Yes, it's been a pain to have to drive to Wellington to catch a flight to Australia, but at least the introduction of Jetstar should make the expense of flying via an Auckland connection more palatable. 
And domestic tourism is where greater and more realistic gains cane be made by Manawatu. Affordable routes that support this should be on the agenda of all stakeholders, rather than getting hung up on what we used to have but don't have now. - Stuff
